**[Anthony McPartlin](/wiki/Anthony_McPartlin "Anthony McPartlin")** ,
[OBE](/wiki/Order_of_the_British_Empire "Order of the British Empire") (born
18 November 1975) and **[Declan Donnelly](/wiki/Declan_Donnelly "Declan
Donnelly")** , [OBE](/wiki/Order_of_the_British_Empire "Order of the British
Empire") (born 25 September 1975), known collectively as **Ant & Dec**, are an
English comedy [TV presenting](/wiki/Television_presenter "Television
presenter"), television producing, acting and former music duo from [Newcastle
upon Tyne](/wiki/Newcastle_upon_Tyne "Newcastle upon Tyne"), England.

The duo first met as actors on the children's television show _[Byker
Grove](/wiki/Byker_Grove "Byker Grove")_ , during which and in their
subsequent pop career they were respectively known as **PJ & Duncan** – the
names of the characters they played on the show. Since then, they have had a
very successful career as television presenters, presenting shows such as
_[SMTV Live](/wiki/SMTV_Live "SMTV Live")_ , _[CD:UK](/wiki/CD:UK "CD:UK")_ ,
_[Friends Like These](/wiki/Friends_Like_These "Friends Like These")_ , _[Pop
Idol](/wiki/Pop_Idol "Pop Idol")_ , _[Ant& Dec's Saturday Night
Takeaway](/wiki/Ant_%26_Dec%27s_Saturday_Night_Takeaway "Ant & Dec's Saturday
Night Takeaway")_, _[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of
Here!](/wiki/I%27m_a_Celebrity...Get_Me_Out_of_Here!_\(UK_TV_series\) "I'm a
Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! \(UK TV series\)")_,
_[PokerFace](/wiki/PokerFace "PokerFace")_ , _[Push the
Button](/wiki/Ant_%26_Dec%27s_Push_the_Button "Ant & Dec's Push the Button")_
, _[Britain's Got Talent](/wiki/Britain%27s_Got_Talent "Britain's Got
Talent")_, _[Red or Black?](/wiki/Red_or_Black%3F "Red or Black?")_ , and
_[Text Santa](/wiki/Text_Santa "Text Santa")_. In 2006, they returned to
acting with the film _[Alien Autopsy](/wiki/Alien_Autopsy_\(film\) "Alien
Autopsy \(film\)")_. The duo presented the annual [Brit
Awards](/wiki/Brit_Awards "Brit Awards") in [2001](/wiki/2001_Brit_Awards
"2001 Brit Awards"), [2015](/wiki/2015_Brit_Awards "2015 Brit Awards") and
[2016](/wiki/2016_Brit_Awards "2016 Brit Awards").

Ant is the taller out of the two at 5 ft 10 in (1.78 m), and Dec is four
inches shorter at 5 ft 6 in (1.68 m). To assist with identification, they
follow the [180-degree rule](/wiki/180-degree_rule "180-degree rule"); with
the exception of some early publicity shots.[1][2]

They have their own production company, Mitre Television,[3] where they
produce their shows.[4] In a 2004 poll for the [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC"), Ant &
Dec were named the eighteenth most influential people in [British
culture](/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom "Culture of the United
Kingdom").[5][6]

## Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant_%26_Dec&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

McPartlin and Donnelly first met while working on the BBC children's drama
_[Byker Grove](/wiki/Byker_Grove "Byker Grove")_ in 1989. After a shaky
start,[7] they soon became best friends.[7] They have achieved such popularity
as a duo that they are hardly ever seen apart on screen. It is reported that
they are each insured against the other's death, with the amount reportedly
being around £1,000,000.[8] Their inseparability has led to their receiving
joint nominations for many awards.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] They
are both managed by the [James Grant
Group](/w/index.php?title=James_Grant_Group&action=edit&redlink=1 "James Grant
Group \(page does not exist\)").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Career[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant_%26_Dec&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Career")]

### Acting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant_%26_Dec&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Acting")]

Although Ant had gained some television experience with a brief stint on the
children's television series _[Why Don't You?](/wiki/Why_Don%27t_You%3F "Why
Don't You?")_, which was broadcast on the [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC"), Dec was the
first of the two to acquire his place on the BBC children's drama _[Byker
Grove](/wiki/Byker_Grove "Byker Grove")_. He joined in 1989, playing Duncan. A
year later, Ant joined the cast to play PJ. Their friendship began when their
storylines collided, creating a friendship off-screen as well as on.[9] Dec
also played a stable boy in the adaptation of the novel _[The Cinder
Path](/wiki/The_Cinder_Path "The Cinder Path")_ in his teenage years.[10] They
also went on to co-star in the 2006 sci-fi comedy movie [_Alien
Autopsy_](/wiki/Alien_Autopsy_\(film\) "Alien Autopsy \(film\)").[11]

### Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant_%26_Dec&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Music")]

Main article: [PJ & Duncan discography](/wiki/PJ_%26_Duncan_discography "PJ &
Duncan discography")

After leaving television, the duo turned their hand to pop music. Their first
single was a song they performed while part of Byker Grove, entitled "Tonight
I'm Free". The single had some success, and the duo went on to record two
albums under their character names of PJ & Duncan. Their most famous hit
during this period was the [BRIT Award](/wiki/BRIT_Awards "BRIT Awards")
nominated "Let's Get Ready To Rhumble", for which the video and moves were
choreographed by Mark Short, who had previously worked with [Tina
Turner](/wiki/Tina_Turner "Tina Turner") and [Peter Andre](/wiki/Peter_Andre
"Peter Andre"). For their third album, the duo reinvented themselves under
their real names of Ant & Dec. The album featured their signature single
"Shout". "[Let's Get Ready To Rhumble](/wiki/Let%27s_Get_Ready_To_Rhumble
"Let's Get Ready To Rhumble")" made a comeback on Saturday Night Takeaway at
the end of the show.

Their final single release was "Falling", which was the track that
subsequently ended their musical career. The track was pulled from the British
charts under the instruction of their record label, Telstar Records, after
claims of copyright infringement were made, brought about by a pop duo, 'And
all because...', who were also managed by Ant and Dec's management team. The
duo claimed that Ant & Dec had stolen the song from them and released it
without their consent. Subsequently, Telstar Records decided not to renew
their existing contract, and they were dropped from the label.

During their time, the pair released sixteen [singles](/wiki/Single_\(music\)
"Single \(music\)") and three studio albums; however, none of their releases
managed to reach number one, with their highest UK chart position being number
three. The duo did, however, reach the top ten in Germany and Japan, and even
had a number-one single in Germany, with their cover of the Everly Brothers'
"All I Have to Do Is Dream". Success also struck in other European countries.
The duo had a short lived revival in the music industry, releasing a song for
the [2002 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2002_FIFA_World_Cup "2002 FIFA World Cup"),
entitled "We're on the Ball". The track peaked at No. 3,[12] being beaten by
[Will Young](/wiki/Will_Young "Will Young") and [Gareth
Gates](/wiki/Gareth_Gates "Gareth Gates"). On 23 March 2013 Ant and Dec
performed "Let's Get Ready To Rhumble" as part of their show _[Ant and Dec's
Saturday Night Takeaway](/wiki/Ant_and_Dec%27s_Saturday_Night_Takeaway "Ant
and Dec's Saturday Night Takeaway")_ which powered the song to number one on
the UK [iTunes](/wiki/ITunes "ITunes") chart and on Sunday 31 March 2013 the
track was revealed as the Official UK Number 1 single on [The Official
Chart](/wiki/The_Official_Chart "The Official Chart") on BBC Radio 1. All
money made from the re-release was donated to charity.[13]

### Presenting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant_%26_Dec&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Presenting")]

#### Children's
television[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant_%26_Dec&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Children's television")]

Ant & Dec got their first presenting job in 1994, while they were still
releasing music under the alias of PJ & Duncan. They co-presented a Saturday-
morning children's show entitled _[Gimme 5](/wiki/Gimme_5_\(TV_series\) "Gimme
5 \(TV series\)")_ , which was broadcast on [CITV](/wiki/CITV "CITV"). The
show only lasted two series before being dropped from the airwaves.[14] In
1995, the duo were once again offered a job on [CBBC](/wiki/CBBC "CBBC"), this
time presenting their own series, entitled _The Ant & Dec Show_. The series
was broadcast from 1995 to 1997, and in 1996, Ant & Dec won two [BAFTA
Awards](/wiki/British_Academy_of_Film_and_Television_Arts "British Academy of
Film and Television Arts"), one for 'Best Children's Show' and one for 'Best
Sketch Comedy Show'.[15] In 1997, a VHS release, entitled _The Ant & Dec Show
– Confidential_, was made available in shops, and featured an hour of the best
bits from three years of the programme, as well as specially recorded sketches
and music videos.[16]

In 1998, the duo switched to [Channel 4](/wiki/Channel_4 "Channel 4"),
presenting an early-evening children's show entitled _Ant & Dec Unzipped_.[17]
This show also won a BAFTA, but was dropped from the airwaves after just one
series.[18] [ITV](/wiki/ITV_\(TV_network\) "ITV \(TV network\)") soon signed
the duo in August 1998,[19] and within weeks, were assigned to present
[ITV1](/wiki/ITV1 "ITV1")'s Saturday morning programmes _[SMTV
Live](/wiki/SMTV_Live "SMTV Live")_ and _[CD:UK](/wiki/CD:UK "CD:UK")_ ,
alongside old friend [Cat Deeley](/wiki/Cat_Deeley "Cat Deeley"). The duo
presented the shows alongside Deeley for three years, becoming the most
popular ITV Saturday morning show. The programme's success was the mix of
games such as Eat My Goal, Wonkey Donkey and Challenge Ant, sketches such as
"Dec Says" and the "Secret of My Success", and the chemistry between Ant, Dec
and Cat. Two _SMTV_ VHS releases, compiling the best bits from both shows,
were released in 2000 and 2001 respectively. Ant & Dec also starred in the
children's TV series _[Engie Benjy](/wiki/Engie_Benjy "Engie Benjy")_ during
their time on _SMTV_.[20][21]

Ant & Dec made their permanent departure from children's television in 2001
after trying out formats like _[Friends Like These](/wiki/Friends_Like_These
"Friends Like These")_ for [BBC One](/wiki/BBC_One "BBC One") in 2000 and
_[Slap Bang with Ant& Dec](/wiki/Slap_Bang_with_Ant_%26_Dec "Slap Bang with
Ant & Dec")_ for ITV in 2001 (which was basically _SMTV_ in the evening even
playing Challenge Ant against adults). They have since said that the main
reason they left _SMTV_ was because the _[Pop Idol](/wiki/Pop_Idol "Pop
Idol")_ live finals were due to begin on Saturday nights on ITV in December
2001.

#### Primetime[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant_%26_Dec&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Primetime")]

Ant & Dec's first primetime presenting job came in the form of [BBC](/wiki/BBC
"BBC") Saturday-night game show _[Friends Like These](/wiki/Friends_Like_These
"Friends Like These")_ , which was first broadcast in 1999 and made them known
as presenters- a shift change from their acting days. The duo presented four
series of the programme between 1999 and 2001.[22] In 2001, the duo's contract
with [ITV](/wiki/ITV_\(TV_network\) "ITV \(TV network\)") was renewed for a
further three years, following their appearances on _SMTV Live_ and _CD:UK_ ,
and received their first primetime presenting job on the station, presenting
brand new Saturday night reality series _[Pop Idol](/wiki/Pop_Idol "Pop
Idol")_ and down to this success they had to leave _SMTV_ behind. _Pop Idol_
was broadcast for only two series before was replaced in 2004 by _[The X
Factor](/wiki/The_X_Factor_\(UK_TV_series\) "The X Factor \(UK TV series\)")_
, to which former [Smash Hits](/wiki/Smash_Hits "Smash Hits") editor [Kate
Thornton](/wiki/Kate_Thornton "Kate Thornton") was assigned presenting duties.

In 2005, as part of the ITV's 50th birthday celebrations, they were back on
television fronting _[Ant& Dec's Gameshow
Marathon](/wiki/Ant_%26_Dec%27s_Gameshow_Marathon "Ant & Dec's Gameshow
Marathon")_, a celebration of some of ITV's most enduring gameshows from the
past 50 years. They hosted _[The Price Is
Right](/wiki/The_Price_Is_Right_\(UK_game_show\) "The Price Is Right \(UK game
show\)")_ , _[Family Fortunes](/wiki/Family_Fortunes "Family Fortunes")_ ,
_[Play Your Cards Right](/wiki/Play_Your_Cards_Right "Play Your Cards Right")_
, _[Bullseye](/wiki/Bullseye_\(UK_game_show\) "Bullseye \(UK game show\)")_ ,
_[Take Your Pick!](/wiki/Take_Your_Pick! "Take Your Pick!")_ , _[The Golden
Shot](/wiki/The_Golden_Shot "The Golden Shot")_ and _[Sale of the
Century](/wiki/Sale_of_the_Century "Sale of the Century")_.

In 2002, Ant & Dec created and presented their own show, entitled _[Ant& Dec's
Saturday Night Takeaway](/wiki/Ant_%26_Dec%27s_Saturday_Night_Takeaway "Ant &
Dec's Saturday Night Takeaway")_. The show has so far run for thirteen series,
with series 14 due to air in early 2017. The first series was not an overall
success, but with the introduction of "Ant & Dec Undercover", "What's Next?",
"Ant v Dec" and "Little Ant and Dec", the show became a hit. During the fourth
series, Dec broke his arm, thumb and suffered a concussion whilst completing a
challenge for the 'Ant vs. Dec' segment of the show. The incident involved
learning how to ride a motorbike and jumping through a ring of fire. During
the challenge, Dec failed to pull hard enough on the throttle of the bike,
causing it to topple over and sending him flying through the air. The accident
caused the pair to miss the _[Comic Relief](/wiki/Comic_Relief "Comic
Relief")_ charity telethon of 2005. In 2006, the first episode of series five
saw the duo abseil down the side of the 22-storey high [London
Studios](/wiki/The_London_Studios "The London Studios"), where the show was
filmed. Two DVDs, a best-bits book and a board game of the series were
released during 2004. The show was rested after 2009 as Ant & Dec said they
were running out of ideas and it became stale, as many of the popular features
such as "Little Ant & Dec" and "Undercover" were dropped. _Saturday Night
Takeaway_ returned in 2013 and was a massive success; Ant & Dec resurrected
previous hit features such as "Undercover", "Little Ant and Dec" (albeit with
a new Little Ant and Dec) Win the Ads and Ant v Dec, with new host [Ashley
Roberts](/wiki/Ashley_Roberts "Ashley Roberts"). They also brought in new
features such as the Supercomputer, Vegas or Bust, the End of the show 'show'
where Ant and Dec perform with an act such as Riverdance or an Orchestra, and
"I'm a Celebrity, get out of my ear!" where they have an earpiece in a celebs
ear and they tell them what to do while being filmed by secret cameras. The
series was such a success that ITV recommissioned it for 2014 even before the
2013 series ended.

In August 2002, Ant & Dec fronted _[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of
Here!](/wiki/I%27m_a_Celebrity...Get_Me_Out_of_Here!_\(UK_TV_series\) "I'm a
Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! \(UK TV series\)")_. They drew their highest
viewing figures to date in February 2004: nearly 15 million tuned in to watch
the third series. In May 2006, they were assigned to present coverage of the
charity football match _[Soccer Aid](/wiki/Soccer_Aid "Soccer Aid")_. They
were then invited back to present coverage of the second match in September
2008 but have been replaced by [Dermot O'Leary](/wiki/Dermot_O%27Leary "Dermot
O'Leary") from 2010 as the match clashed with _[Britain's Got
Talent](/wiki/Britain%27s_Got_Talent "Britain's Got Talent")_. In June 2006,
they announced they had created a new game-show format for ITV, entitled
_[PokerFace](/wiki/PokerFace_\(game_show\) "PokerFace \(game show\)")_. The
show featured members of the public gambling high stakes of money in an
attempt to win the ultimate prize. The first series began airing on 10 July
2006, and was aired for seven consecutive nights. The second series was
broadcast in early 2007, and saw a move to a prime-time Saturday slot. Ratings
for the series fell to below 3.5 million, and the series was subsequently axed
in March 2007. A board game of the format was released in 2008.

In April 2007, the duo signed a two-year [golden
handcuffs](/wiki/Golden_handcuffs "Golden handcuffs") deal with ITV,
reportedly worth [£](/wiki/Pound_sterling "Pound sterling")40 million,
securing their career at the station until the end of 2009.[23] In June 2007,
they were offered the job of presenters on new ITV reality platform _Britain
's Got Talent_ by [Simon Cowell](/wiki/Simon_Cowell "Simon Cowell"). The
series features contestants aiming to win £100,000 and spot on the bill at the
[Royal Variety Performance](/wiki/Royal_Variety_Performance "Royal Variety
Performance"), while performing and being judged by Cowell, actress [Amanda
Holden](/wiki/Amanda_Holden "Amanda Holden") and former [Daily
Mirror](/wiki/Daily_Mirror "Daily Mirror") editor [Piers
Morgan](/wiki/Piers_Morgan "Piers Morgan"). The series was highly successful,
drawing in nearly 12 million viewers. A second series was broadcast in May
2008, and drew in nearly 14.5 million viewers.[24] They have since returned to
present ten series of the show, and have also had a regular feature on the
[ITV2](/wiki/ITV2 "ITV2") spin-off show _[Britain's Got More
Talent](/wiki/Britain%27s_Got_More_Talent "Britain's Got More Talent")_.

The pair filmed a series of six episodes for a new American game show, _[Wanna
Bet?](/wiki/Wanna_Bet%3F "Wanna Bet?")_ , in November 2007. The episodes was
broadcast in 2008, but failed to attract enough interest for a second series
to be commissioned.[25] _What You Wrote_ , another format created by the duo,
was due to air in Autumn 2008 but was reportedly axed by
[ITV](/wiki/ITV_\(TV_network\) "ITV \(TV network\)").[26] In 2010, the duo
debuted a replacement for _Ant & Dec's Saturday Night Takeaway_, entitled
_[Ant& Dec's Push the Button](/wiki/Ant_%26_Dec%27s_Push_the_Button "Ant &
Dec's Push the Button")_. The series was a success albeit not in the same way
as _Saturday Night Takeaway_ , and a second run of the programme was broadcast
in 2011 but Ant and Dec later dropped the show in favour of reviving _Saturday
Night Takeaway_.

Ant & Dec have also presented the game show _[Red or
Black?](/wiki/Red_or_Black%3F "Red or Black?")_ , a creation of Cowell's,
airing live on ITV in 2011 with a second series in 2012, but this was not a
ratings success and was cancelled after the second series. On 24 December
2011, they presented ITV's charity initiative _[Text Santa](/wiki/Text_Santa
"Text Santa")_ with [Holly Willoughby](/wiki/Holly_Willoughby "Holly
Willoughby"). _Text Santa_ returned in 2012, 2013 and 2014 with Ant & Dec co-
hosting alongside [Christine Bleakley](/wiki/Christine_Bleakley "Christine
Bleakley"), [Phillip Schofield](/wiki/Phillip_Schofield "Phillip Schofield"),
[Holly Willoughby](/wiki/Holly_Willoughby "Holly Willoughby"), [Alesha
Dixon](/wiki/Alesha_Dixon "Alesha Dixon") and [Paddy
McGuinness](/wiki/Paddy_McGuinness "Paddy McGuinness").

In January 2016, Ant and Dec presented _When Ant and Dec Met The Prince: 40
Years of The Prince 's Trust_, a one-off documentary for ITV.[27] In 2016,
they also presented _The Queen 's 90th Birthday Celebration_, broadcast live
on ITV.[28]

In November 2016 the pair signed a new three-year deal with
[ITV](/wiki/ITV_\(TV_network\) "ITV \(TV network\)") estimated to be worth
£30m.[29]

### Other
activities[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant_%26_Dec&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Other activities")]

In 2006, a celebration of the show _[Spitting Image](/wiki/Spitting_Image
"Spitting Image")_ saw Ant and Dec having their own puppets made. They have
also been made into cartoon characters on the comedy show _[2DTV](/wiki/2DTV
"2DTV")_ , and face masks in _[Avid Merrion](/wiki/Avid_Merrion "Avid
Merrion")'_s _[Bo Selecta](/wiki/Bo_Selecta "Bo Selecta")_. Waxworks of the
duo could once be found in London's _[Madame Tussauds](/wiki/Madame_Tussauds
"Madame Tussauds")_.

In April 2008, it was reported that Ant & Dec's production company, Gallowgate
Productions, had purchased the rights to _Byker Grove_ and _SMTV Live_ , after
the production companies that made them, [Zenith
Entertainment](/wiki/Zenith_Entertainment "Zenith Entertainment") and Blaze
Television, had both gone bankrupt in 2007. According to reports, the duo
decided to purchase the rights to stop digital channels showing repeats of the
programmes.[30] On 28 September 2008, it was reported that the pair were
attacked by the [Taliban](/wiki/Taliban "Taliban") whilst in
[Afghanistan](/wiki/Afghanistan "Afghanistan") to present a [Pride of Britain
Award](/wiki/Pride_of_Britain_Awards "Pride of Britain Awards").[31]

In December 2008, the duo starred in a seasonal advert, their first in seven
years, for the supermarket chain [Sainsbury's](/wiki/Sainsbury%27s
"Sainsbury's"). The duo appeared alongside chef [Jamie
Oliver](/wiki/Jamie_Oliver "Jamie Oliver").[32] In March 2009, the duo filmed
a short film for inclusion on [Comic Relief](/wiki/Comic_Relief "Comic
Relief"), which highlighted their story upon visiting a community centre for
young carers in the North East. In September 2009, the duo released their
official autobiography, entitled "Ooh! What a Lovely Pair. Our Story".[33] In
October 2010, the duo appeared in several [Nintendo](/wiki/Nintendo
"Nintendo") adverts playing both the [Wii](/wiki/Wii "Wii")[34] and [Nintendo
DS](/wiki/Nintendo_DS "Nintendo DS").[35]

In 2011 and 2014, they both appeared on the [ITV2](/wiki/ITV2 "ITV2") comedy
panel show _[Celebrity Juice](/wiki/Celebrity_Juice "Celebrity Juice")_. From
February 2013 to March 2015 they appeared in adverts for supermarket
[Morrisons](/wiki/Morrisons "Morrisons"). Since February 2016, they have
appeared in adverts for car company [Suzuki](/wiki/Suzuki "Suzuki").

In 2015, the pair made a cameo appearance on the [U.S.](/wiki/United_States
"United States") adaptation of Saturday Night Takeaway, [NBC](/wiki/NBC
"NBC")'s _[Best Time Ever with Neil Patrick
Harris](/wiki/Best_Time_Ever_with_Neil_Patrick_Harris "Best Time Ever with
Neil Patrick Harris")_. The duo are also executive producers on the show.[36]

### OBEs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant_%26_Dec&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: OBEs")]

On 10 June 2016 it was announced that the duo would be awarded [OBE](/wiki/OBE
"OBE") status by Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II at an investiture later that
year. The pair said they were both "shocked, but incredibly honoured."[37]
Anthony McPartlin and Declan Donnelly collected their awards for services to
broadcasting and entertainment at Buckingham Palace from Prince Charles on 27
January 2017. Following the brief ceremony, the pair said:

“ | We're humbled and honoured and ecstatic about the whole thing. We hope it can inspire young people from backgrounds like ours that things like this do happen to us sometimes. Put your head down and work hard and you can achieve what you want. You can end up in Buckingham Palace. | ”  
---|---|---  
  
## Controversies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant_%26_Dec&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Controversies")]

Law firm [Olswang](/wiki/Olswang "Olswang") were commissioned to investigate
the [2005 British Comedy Awards](/wiki/British_Comedy_Awards#2005 "British
Comedy Awards") when the producers overturned the voting public's first
choice, _[The Catherine Tate Show](/wiki/The_Catherine_Tate_Show "The
Catherine Tate Show")_ in favour of _Ant and Dec 's Saturday Night Takeaway_
for the People's Choice Award. The incident was also the subject of an
investigation by media regulator [Ofcom](/wiki/Ofcom "Ofcom").[38][39]

Following allegations of fraud in 2007, an investigation by auditors [Deloitte
Touche Tohmatsu](/wiki/Deloitte_Touche_Tohmatsu "Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu")
discovered that two shows, _Ant & Dec's Gameshow Marathon_ and _Ant & Dec's
Saturday Night Takeaway_, had defrauded viewers participating in phone-ins.
The programmes were subject to a further investigation by [Ofcom](/wiki/Ofcom
"Ofcom") which found that between January 2003 and October 2006 _Ant & Dec's
Saturday Night Takeaway_ had:[39][40]

  * selected competition finalists before the telephone lines were announced as closed
  * staggered the selection of competition finalists which meant that viewers entering the competition did not have a fair and equal chance of winning
  * selected finalists on the basis of their suitability to be on television and where they lived
  * selected an individual already known to the production team to be placed on the shortlist of potential winners and who went on to win the competition

and between September and October 2005, _Ant & Dec's Gameshow Marathon_ had:

  * on six occasions in the Prize Mountain competition, selected winners based on their suitability to be on screen
  * failed to account for almost half of the competition entries

The pair were ridiculed for their alleged participation in the fraud on the
front cover of the satirical magazine _[Private Eye](/wiki/Private_Eye
"Private Eye")_.[41]

On 10 September 2008, Ant & Dec announced that the frauds "will never happen
again", insisting that a "high-tech system" and strict rules will ensure
viewers cannot lose out with poorly monitored premium rate phone lines.[42]

On 30 September 2008, it was reported that Ant & Dec were being sued for
[$](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar")30 million by [Greek
American](/wiki/Greek_American "Greek American") stand-up comedian and actor
[ANT](/wiki/ANT_\(comedian\) "ANT \(comedian\)") for using his name in the
United States. The lawsuit, among other things, alleges trademark infringement
and fraud.[43] The suit was dismissed in May 2010.[44] The pair have had a UK
registered trademark for 'Ant & Dec' in the category of 'Entertainment
services' since 2003.[45]

## Acting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant_%26_Dec&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Acting")]

They have, albeit infrequently, returned to acting. They played themselves in
the film _[Love Actually](/wiki/Love_Actually "Love Actually")_[46] (in which
[Bill Nighy](/wiki/Bill_Nighy "Bill Nighy")'s character addressed Dec as "Ant
or Dec"). They have returned to their [Geordie](/wiki/Geordie "Geordie") roots
in a one-off tribute to _[The Likely Lads](/wiki/The_Likely_Lads "The Likely
Lads")_[47] and also by returning to _Byker Grove_ for Geoff's
funeral.[48][49]

In 1998, the pair starred in the [pantomime](/wiki/Pantomime "Pantomime")
_[Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs](/wiki/Snow_White "Snow White")_ at
[Sunderland](/wiki/Sunderland,_Tyne_and_Wear "Sunderland, Tyne and Wear")'s
[Empire Theatre](/wiki/Sunderland_Empire_Theatre "Sunderland Empire Theatre")
alongside Donnelly's partner at the time [Clare
Buckfield](/wiki/Clare_Buckfield "Clare Buckfield"). The show was financially
unsuccessful, making £20,000 less than it cost to stage, with the duo footing
a large share of the shortfall.[50]

Ant & Dec's most recent acting appearance was in the film _[Alien
Autopsy](/wiki/Alien_Autopsy_\(film\) "Alien Autopsy \(film\)")_ released in
April 2006.[51] The film gained positive reviews with critics praising the
pair's acting performance, but lost more than half of its budget at the box
office. It has since gained a [cult following](/wiki/Cult_following "Cult
following") from fans of the pair.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] In 2013
they reprised their roles as P.J and Duncan on [Ant & Dec's Saturday Night
Takeaway](/wiki/Ant_%26_Dec%27s_Saturday_Night_Takeaway "Ant & Dec's Saturday
Night Takeaway").
